awd_titl_txt: ATD: Algorithms for Data Analysis on Abstract Manifolds
awd_abstract_narration:
This research program concerns the development of new mathematical algorithms for identifying critical information in data sets that has the potential to reveal biological or chemical threats to humans.  The starting point for this work is the observation that modeling a threat over variations in its appearance serves as the foundation of robust detection algorithms.  Mathematical tools from geometry and topology enable the design of algorithms for extracting information from sets of data that enhance traditional processing methods, leading to smarter sensors.  The graduate students trained in this program will earn doctorates in mathematics while the undergraduates will have the opportunity to be mentored on topics of national interest early in their careers. 

This research addresses the development of mathematical modeling algorithms for data on abstract manifolds.   In contrast to data clouds captured by sensors generating points that exist as a configuration in Euclidean space, this project encodes data as points on matrix manifolds.  The mathematical framework requires only three features: the geometric context, the notion of distance between two points, and the ability to compute the perturbation of one point in the direction of another.  Additionally, one can exploit information related to the statistics of points on matrix manifolds.  This research program aims to explore the geometry of these spaces for the purposes of anomaly detection and characterization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research concerned the development of new mathematical algorithms for identifying critical information in data capable of revealing potential threats to humans. We focused primarily on the exploration of geometric tools for characterizing large data sets.  This approach involved the mathematical representation of data, together with the search for discriminating features with the aid of machine learning.  These tools were applied to data sets of biological and chemical agents in the atmosphere as measured by hyperspectral imaging systems, in addition to clinical data sets of human subjects exposed to respiratory viruses such as influenza and RSV.  We developed a mathematical framework centered on encoding massive data sets on special manifolds. This approach permitted the investigation of geometric, combinatorial and statistical tools for searching, detecting and classifying the patterns of interest. Our primary focus was on algorithms where the abstract points reside on Grassmannians, and their generalizations, flag manifolds.  We have observed that subspace approximations to sets of data capture a variation of state that translates to robust classification algorithms.  Specifically, we developed new algorithms for threat detection in this geometric framework.

This interdisciplinary research program addressed a major challenge in research related to National Security. The research was conducted by faculty and students from the Departments of Mathematics and Computer Science at Colorado State University, providing the students with unique multidisciplinary experience with research integration in education.  This award supported 7 different graduate students in Mathematics and Computer Science and resulted in 6 PhD dissertations and 5 Masters theses. In addition, 29 papers were published in journals and conferences, and over 30 presentations occurred to disseminate the work supported by this award.

We maintained a Threat Detection Data Set Repository for the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) for participants in this program to use for algorithm development. This repository facilitated the development of algorithms specifically on data sets of interest to DTRA.  The results of this research program have the potential to be useful to other research efforts in support of the National Defense.  A suite of courses in Linear Algebra for Data Science were also developed over the period of this grant that included many of the subspace ideas that were developed during the period of this award.
